greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of different eventual period lengths for power sequences mod n; i.e., number of different period lengths of repeating digits of 1/n in different bases.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: Number of divisors of reduced totient function: a(n) = A000005(A002322(n)).
example: Modulo 5, powers of 1,6,11 etc. are 1,1,1,1,1,1,...; of 2,7,12 etc. are 1,2,4,3,1,2,4,3,...; of 3,8,13 etc. are 1,3,4,2,1,3,4,2,...; of 4,9,14 etc. are 1,4,1,4,1,4,...; of 5,10,15 etc. are 1,0,0,0,0,... So the eventual period lengths are 1,4,4,2,1 giving three distinct lengths, so a(5)=3.
program: A002322(n) = lcm(znstar(n)[2]); \\ This function from _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Aug 04 2012
xref: This is the number of different values of rows of the square array A066799.
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Dec 20 2001
